At 15:23 14/11/2005, you wrote:
>I think I solved this the following trivial way;
>
>Input nodes are labeled depth=0, outputnodes are labeled depth=1. When a
>connection is split, it's labeled depth=(parent1.depth+parent2.depth)/2.
>
>Since splitting connections is the only way to introduce new nodes, all
>nodes should be labeled by the depth they were created at.
>
>to prevent recurrent connecitons, don't connect a node to a node with a
>lower depth.
>
>Seems to work for me and executes in linear time?
>
>Am I missing something really complicated here?

Hi Mattias,

         I don't think you are missing anything.  I think basically 
we reached the conclusion that there are two families of algorithm for this:

1) some sort of arbitrary, or average (as you do) or incremental (as 
I do) parameter is assigned to each node, and all connections formed 
must obey the direction of this parameter (say lower to higher).

2) analyse the network to see if recurrence is being formed and 
forbid the connection if it is not

The pros and cons are:

(1) is faster than (2)

(1) will not connect some valid topologies - I believe it can make 
any topology, but some of them in can not assemble from every valid precursor

(2) leaves some "conventions" undefined, e.g. nodes which are neither 
up- nor down-stream of each other, these conventions can then get set 
incompatibly in different strains

These last two points define the difference between the two 
approaches.  (1) defines all conventions in advance, which means they 
will always remain compatible, but limits some directions of 
growth.  (2) leaves some conventions unspecified, which allows any 
valid direction of growth, but allows competing conventions to arise 
in different parts of the population.

A third approach, might be to leave conventions undefined at first, 
but then as soon as one individual defines one, copy that restriction 
across the whole population...

         Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
